Let a nigga reach, I teach, it’s just me vers’ me
 I’m MJ in the 45 vers’ 23

In one of the most famous games of his career, Michael Jordan wore the number 45 a couple times during his second stint in the NBA. Vic is saying he is only competing against himself for the title, like MJ wearing 45 playing against himself, as he is synonymous with the number 23.

I’m living proof the Messiah can die and be resurrected
 I survive, y’all crucifying me for my message
 Might, pull up in a Lam’ to silence you I’m a shepherd
 My truth, overrule my desire to be respected

Jesus Christ, often called the Messiah, died and rose three days later. Vic is using this metaphor as a way to talk about not only his career, as many believe it died and came back, but also how he almost got assassinated, like he will talk about later.

Jesus is also referred to as a lamb and a shepherd. Vic is saying that he might drive in his Lamborghini on his way to silence, or kill you. In the same way shepherds are known to silence their sheep when needed.

Finally, Jesus came to spread his message, the Gospel. Gospel means truth in its origins. Just like Jesus, sharing his message is more important to him than being respected or like by the people. The people hated Jesus so much they crucified him, and Vic is afraid by spreading his Gospel, he will achieve the same fate.
Damage the pussy like a lateral then I pass her off

Vic cleverly uses the “ke” sound in “like”, and the “a” that follows to sneak in the word collateral, which refers back to the claim that he “damages” pussies. The “pass her off” part, on the other hand, is simply a play on the term “Lateral pass”, claiming that he is not one to cling on to any girl and once he cums he’s done.
In the field where the fathers ain’t coach us

Note the multiplication within this rhyme scheme; 8 + 8 + 16 + 23 + 45 = 100.

Never afraid to address the elephant in the room – “keeping it a hundred,” Vic confronts a list of sensitive topics. Fatherless homes, the genocide of indigenous people, Eurocentrism, and his multi-interpretational view of Dogma. Hailing from the socioeconomically notorious streets of Chicago’s South Side, Vic and his entourage’s luck changed by the success of his Rap career, allowing them to live lavishly. Nice wordplay with the term “field” – a colloquialism for the “streets” – and the fatherly role of a sports coach.

Eminem, aka Slim Shady, appeared on Soul Intent’s 1995 self-titled mixtape at 23-years old. Em was also 23-years old during the making of his solo debut Infinite in 1996, although released after his October 17 birthday. Em also established the radio station Shade 45.

During his first comeback for the 1994-95 season, Michael Jordan graced the court wearing the number 45 before switching back to the iconic 23. Vic cleverly weaved in Em’s nickname and the age of when he got his first “M” – million dollars.

Also, the mention of the .45 caliber gun helps carry over to the following bars about the actual lethal consequences of messing with him. Playing with the concept of “being 100” or a “real nigga,” which has a dual definition.
I got a lot of beef like I had four stomachs
Vic draws a simile to compare his fight with his competition with a cow (beef); which has a Ruminant digestive system, meaning that it has a stomach with four compartments.
I’m still ballin’ on niggas that’s game, blouses

Charlie Murphy relates a story of a basketball pick-up game between the Murphy brothers and friends versus Prince and The Revolution on a skit on the Chappelle’s Show. The match would be known as ‘Shirts Vs Blouses’ due to the inappropriate dress by Prince’s team.
I’m Gil Scott but my revolution is televised
A shout to Gil Scott and his classic poem, “The Revolution Will Not Be Televised”
Pourin’ out drinks for you champ, word to Noreaga

A shout out to the Drink Champs podcast hosted by Noreaga (now known as N.O.R.E) and DJ EFN.

On the show, N.O.R.E pours alcoholic drinks for his guests, and drinks throughout the conversation.
Maya Angelou in a trap full of caged birds

‘The trap’ refers to a rough neighbourhood or spot where drugs are sold. While ‘caged birds,’ or simply “birds,” is a colloquialism for 36 ounces of cocaine.

This is also a reference to Maya Angelou’s autobiography, I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1969). Vic previously referenced the book on “BETHLEHEM / SC FREESTYLE”:

I’m drinking from the whites-only fountain of youth
They heard the caged bird sing, so I bought me a coupe
